text:
By creating opportunities for
the next generation of women,

we can build communities and
leave a lasting positive impact.

Continue to support each other,
advocating for each other.

Being a compassionate
leader who sees opportunity
where others see obstacles.
Lifting as we climb.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

I really look up to the
case protagonist Gale King.

She was the chief HR
officer at a large company.

What stood out to me the
most was her emphasis

on people and EQ, the importance
of making your employees

feel valued and heard, and
how that can directly impact
the value of your company.

Jenn Braus is a female case
protagonist in the "Financial

Management of
Smaller Firms" class.

She came to class, and
I got the cold call.

Those ones always stick
with you a little extra.

Jenn's story really
showed me that you

can think critically about what
your life will be like and pick

a career that is optimized
for the choices and the life
that you want to live.
Brooke Boyarsky Pratt.
She started knownwell

healthcare company
focused on obesity care.

It was great learning
about her journey

about finding her
passion, and then once she

found it, the kind of
conviction that she

had with pursuing an idea that a
lot of people kept pushing down.

And as someone
earlier in my career,

I looked toward the
stories of women

like that to think about
my own path in healthcare.
Debbie Lovich.
It's called the "Balancing Act."

She was a partner at
Boston Consulting Group,

and I was also a consultant
before business school.

I think we're
often told that you

have to pick between having
a really influential career
and prioritizing your family.

She didn't give up
one or the other,

but found ways to
integrate both.

There are so many different ways
to have an impact on the world

and you don't have to follow
the preset path for yourself.

What do you want your
life to look like?
What values do you have?

Find mentorship and really
lean into the core capabilities
that you have.

Whatever your goal
is, add 10% or 20%.

Don't limit yourself
based on anything.

Know that if you work really
hard, if you surround yourself

with the right group
of people, and if you

set really, really
big goals, you
will be able to achieve them.

We're seeing female leaders
start billion-dollar companies,

be game-changers for
industries, and reshaping

what we thought the business
world and leadership looked
like in the past.

Clay Christensen, an iconic
Harvard Business School

professor, taught
that management
can be a life-changing thing.

That really resonates
with my own values

and how I hope to
exist in the world,

to allow people
who work with you

and who work for you to
leave every day feeling seen
and feeling empowered.

Being willing to
create opportunities,

because that's how we all
ended up in the places
that we're at today.

And if we can do that
for the next generation,

it continues to create a
virtuous cycle for fostering
future female business leaders.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
